articles.headline: What Are We Going to Wear?
articles.snippet: Predicting the future is a huge part of retail. Trend forecasters are back at it, eyes more on TikTok than the runway, adapting to a reality no one could have predicted.
articles.abstract: Predicting the future is a huge part of retail. Trend forecasters are back at it, eyes more on TikTok than the runway, adapting to a reality no one could have predicted.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ties. Dozens of patterns, colors and fabrics — discounts on 300 different styles. That’s what Nordstrom had planned for its big sale last July. The company had worked with trend forecasters and talked with designers, but history was its best guide. Based on previous sales, the retailer was confident that shoppers would be seeking out deals on office wear like ties, dresses, heels and handbags. By the end of February, it had ordered everything it planned to sell at the event.

articles.headline: Stocks Drop as Wall Street’s Unease Stretches to a Fourth Day
articles.snippet: Investors have been adjusting their expectations for interest rates, leading to a turbulent stretch for the stock market.
articles.abstract: Investors have been adjusting their expectations for interest rates, leading to a turbulent stretch for the stock market.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stocks had their biggest daily decline in over a month on Friday, capping a week of turbulence on Wall Street as investors struggled to calibrate their expectations for inflation and interest rates.
articles.byline: By Matt Phillips and Jeanna Smialek

articles.headline: Targeting Biden, Catholic Bishops Advance Controversial Communion Plan
articles.snippet: The decision was aimed at the nation’s second Catholic president and exposed bitter divisions in American Catholicism.
articles.abstract: The decision was aimed at the nation’s second Catholic president and exposed bitter divisions in American Catholicism.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Roman Catholic bishops of the United States, flouting a warning from the Vatican, have overwhelmingly voted to draft guidance on the sacrament of the Eucharist, advancing a push by conservative bishops to deny President Biden communion because of his support of abortion rights.

articles.headline: A Millennial Economist Helps Power a Tax Evasion ‘Brain Trust’
articles.snippet: Natasha Sarin, a protégé of Larry Summers, is taking a leading role developing tax policy at the Treasury Department — to some progressive Democrats’ chagrin.
articles.abstract: Natasha Sarin, a protégé of Larry Summers, is taking a leading role developing tax policy at the Treasury Department — to some progressive Democrats’ chagrin.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the Biden administration hunts for revenue to pay for trillions of dollars in infrastructure, education, child care and other investments, it has focused on a seemingly simple strategy: Mobilize the Internal Revenue Service to crack down on tax cheats.

articles.headline: The Supreme Court’s Newest Justices Produce Some Unexpected Results
articles.snippet: In the term so far, including two major decisions on Thursday, the court’s expanded conservative majority is fractured and its liberals are often on the winning side.
articles.abstract: In the term so far, including two major decisions on Thursday, the court’s expanded conservative majority is fractured and its liberals are often on the winning side.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The arrival of Justice Amy Coney Barrett in October seemed to create a 6-to-3 conservative juggernaut that would transform the Supreme Court.

articles.headline: How Republican States Are Expanding Their Power Over Elections
articles.snippet: In Georgia, Republicans are removing Democrats of color from local boards. In Arkansas, they have stripped election control from county authorities. And they are expanding their election power in many other states.
articles.abstract: In Georgia, Republicans are removing Democrats of color from local boards. In Arkansas, they have stripped election control from county authorities. And they are expanding their election power in many other states.
articles.lead_paragraph: LaGRANGE, Ga. — Lonnie Hollis has been a member of the Troup County election board in West Georgia since 2013. A Democrat and one of two Black women on the board, she has advocated Sunday voting, helped voters on Election Days and pushed for a new precinct location at a Black church in a nearby town.
articles.byline: By Nick Corasaniti and Reid J. Epstein

articles.headline: For Biden, Iranian Hard-liner May Be Best Path to Restoring Nuclear Deal
articles.snippet: The next six weeks before a new government takes office in Tehran may be a unique window for clinching an agreement that Iran’s leadership has been delaying.
articles.abstract: The next six weeks before a new government takes office in Tehran may be a unique window for clinching an agreement that Iran’s leadership has been delaying.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Iran’s announcement on Saturday that an ultraconservative former head of the judiciary, Ebrahim Raisi, has been elected president now touches off an unpredictable diplomatic drama: The ascension of a hard-line government in Iran may actually present the Biden administration with a brief opportunity to restore the 2015 nuclear deal with the country.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Farnaz Fassihi

articles.headline: Los Angeles Just Elected a Liberal D.A. He’s Already Facing a Recall Effort.
articles.snippet: George Gascón is facing an intense backlash for enacting the sorts of policies demanded by protesters after the killing of George Floyd.
articles.abstract: George Gascón is facing an intense backlash for enacting the sorts of policies demanded by protesters after the killing of George Floyd.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — From inside the walls of Folsom State Prison, the two inmates, one a convicted murderer, clinked their cups of prison moonshine in a toast to the new district attorney of Los Angeles, George Gascón.

articles.headline: Departure of U.S. Contractors Poses Myriad Problems for Afghan Military
articles.snippet: It is not just U.S. troops who are withdrawing from Afghanistan. Thousands of private contractors — who help keep the Afghan Air Force flying, among other tasks — are leaving as well.
articles.abstract: It is not just U.S. troops who are withdrawing from Afghanistan. Thousands of private contractors — who help keep the Afghan Air Force flying, among other tasks — are leaving as well.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — An Afghan Air Force UH-60 Black Hawk helicopter, shelled while on the ground by the Taliban on Wednesday, sat helpless at a small outpost in the country’s southeast, its burning and damaged airframe displayed in a video on Twitter.
articles.byline: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Dumb Money No More: How David Ellison Became a Hollywood High Flier
articles.snippet: When the young Oracle heir entered the entertainment industry, no one expected much. Instead, he’s built the rarest of businesses — a thriving, all-audiences, independent studio.
articles.abstract: When the young Oracle heir entered the entertainment industry, no one expected much. Instead, he’s built the rarest of businesses — a thriving, all-audiences, independent studio.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Fifteen years ago, when a 23-year-old David Ellison rolled into Hollywood with oodles of trust-fund cash, entertainment insiders licked their jackal lips: Oh, the fleecing we will do!

articles.headline: How Do They Say Economic Recovery? ‘I Quit.’
articles.snippet: With new opportunities and a different perspective as the pandemic eases, workers are choosing to leave their jobs in record numbers.
articles.abstract: With new opportunities and a different perspective as the pandemic eases, workers are choosing to leave their jobs in record numbers.
articles.lead_paragraph: At some point early this year, Justin Hoffman concluded that he was being underpaid.

articles.headline: New York Faces Lasting Economic Toll Even as Pandemic Passes
articles.snippet: The city’s prosperity is heavily dependent on patterns of work and travel that may be irreversibly altered.
articles.abstract: The city’s prosperity is heavily dependent on patterns of work and travel that may be irreversibly altered.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the national economy recovers from the pandemic and begins to take off, New York City is lagging, with changing patterns of work and travel threatening the engines that have long powered its jobs and prosperity.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz, Patrick McGeehan, Nicole Hong and Gabriela Bhaskar

articles.headline: Liz Cheney’s Unlikely Journey From G.O.P. Royalty to Republican Outcast
articles.snippet: Dick Cheney always saw doomsday threats from America’s enemies. His daughter is in a lonely battle against what both see as a danger to American democracy: Donald J. Trump.
articles.abstract: Dick Cheney always saw doomsday threats from America’s enemies. His daughter is in a lonely battle against what both see as a danger to American democracy: Donald J. Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: CASPER, Wyo. — Representative Liz Cheney was holed up in a secure undisclosed location of the Dick Cheney Federal Building, recounting how she got an alarmed phone call from her father on Jan. 6.

articles.headline: Scorching Hot in Phoenix: What It’s Like to Work in 115 Degrees
articles.snippet: Phoenix is facing a double heat and housing crisis that is falling hardest on people who have to suffer the sun.
articles.abstract: Phoenix is facing a double heat and housing crisis that is falling hardest on people who have to suffer the sun.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — As the sun rose on another day of record-breaking heat, Juan Gutierrez and his construction crew were already sweating through their long-sleeve shirts. It was 91 degrees, and workers in a subdivision called Desert Oasis were racing to nail together the wooden skeletons of $380,000 homes that had sold before they were even built.
articles.byline: By Jack Healy and Juan Arredondo

articles.headline: In Rift With Biden, a Dramatic Show of Force by a Conservative Catholic Movement
articles.snippet: A vote by the U.S. bishops was the most dramatic example of the conservative Catholic movement’s reach since Joseph R. Biden was elected. But the contingent had been gaining strength throughout the Trump era.
articles.abstract: A vote by the U.S. bishops was the most dramatic example of the conservative Catholic movement’s reach since Joseph R. Biden was elected. But the contingent had been gaining strength throughout the Trump era.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Pope Francis and President Biden, both liberals, are the two most high-profile Roman Catholics in the world.
articles.byline: By Elizabeth Dias and Ruth Graham

articles.lead_paragraph: Last month, I texted Tucker Carlson to ask him a question that was on my mind: “Did you get vaccinated?”

articles.headline: As Lumber Prices Fall, the Threat of Inflation Loses Its Bite
articles.snippet: Costs soared partly because of do-it-yourselfers’ spending stimulus checks, but a month of declines show that consumers aren’t about to trigger runaway increases.
articles.abstract: Costs soared partly because of do-it-yourselfers’ spending stimulus checks, but a month of declines show that consumers aren’t about to trigger runaway increases.
articles.lead_paragraph: From sawmills to store shelves to your own hammer swings, lumber can tell you a lot about what’s going on in the economy right now.

articles.headline: From Nobel Hero to Driver of War, Ethiopia’s Leader Faces Voters
articles.snippet: Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed plunged Ethiopia into a war in the Tigray region that spawned atrocities and famine. On Monday, his country goes to the polls.
articles.abstract: Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed plunged Ethiopia into a war in the Tigray region that spawned atrocities and famine. On Monday, his country goes to the polls.
articles.lead_paragraph: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia — As war raged in northern Ethiopia, and the region barreled toward its worst famine in decades, a senior American envoy flew to the Ethiopian capital last month in the hope of persuading Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed to pull his country out of a destructive spiral that many fear is tearing it apart.

articles.headline: Supreme Court Backs Payments to Student-Athletes in N.C.A.A. Case
articles.snippet: The association argued that the payments were a threat to amateurism and that barring them did not violate the antitrust laws.
articles.abstract: The association argued that the payments were a threat to amateurism and that barring them did not violate the antitrust laws.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court unanimously ruled on Monday that the N.C.A.A. could not bar relatively modest payments to student-athletes, a decision that underscored the growing challenges to a college sports system that generates huge sums for schools but provides little or no compensation to the players.
articles.byline: By Adam Liptak and Alan Blinder
